Question:
It was good to have the house full of people again; it had been far too quiet since the last of his seven daughters had left for college--seven daughters with seven different majors at seven different schools.  About the only thing they had in common was that they were each dating an athlete, although none of them played the same sport--one was even on his school's fencing team.  He was surprised all the boyfriends had come for Christmas dinner, but he supposed that since he was picking up the tab for the airfare, that a free trip to Hawaii in the winter had something to do with it.  Each of his first three daughters had gone to Ivy League schools--one even to his alma mater at Harvard; his next two ended up at the University of California, at Los Angeles and Berkeley; and his two youngest got accepted to schools abroad--the University of Tokyo had been a bit of a surprise.  Next year, after seven straight years--and for the first time this millennium--he wouldn't be attending a high-school graduation.
"Honey, we're ready to eat.  Can you get Hank, Ian, James and Kyle?  They're in the backyard playing football.  The other boys wanted to test themselves against the star quarterback," his wife called from the dining room.
The math major said, "I'll get them Dad!"
As everyone filed into the dining room, the oldest sister was rehashing the whose-school-and-major-is-better argument with her younger sister about whether Yale or Princeton was a better school and whether history or philosophy was a more useful major.  The argument was practically a Christmas tradition by now.
The table was arranged with the parents at the two ends and each of the couples seated across from each other with boys seated next to girls along each side.  As usual, Angelina and Danica were sitting next to their parents.  Curiously, all the athletes that used a ball in their sport were sitting on the same side of the table.  Christie, Electra and Edward took their seats first.
Once everyone was seated the youngest coyly observed, "I see the biologist is sitting between the two fighters but I'm sitting between the two best passers at the table."
"You'd better not make any passes yourself!" Farrah icily replied.  She hadn't forgiven her sister for stealing her boyfriend when they were in high school and was not happy to see her seated next to her boyfriend now.
"Lighten up, Farrah" the biology major joked.  "He wasn't even that cute."
"He was adorable!" the youngest interjected.
"Everyone's entitled to their opinion," said Brooke.  "Let's eat!"
The daughter in the middle seat stood up and said, "We have an announcement to make!" After a dramatic pause she screamed "we're getting married!" and flashed the new diamond ring on her finger.  The youngest sister squealed with delight at the news.  Her fiance joked to his future mother-in-law, "I think she said yes just so she can wear the monogrammed sweater you gave me for Christmas."  The baseball player next to her asked her fiance, "Wow, what'd that rock set you back?"
"This calls for a toast!" roared Dad.
"Oh Honey, that's wonderful news!" Mom gushed.  "I just happen to have some champagne right here.  Lars, I know you don't drink alcohol, but would you mind pouring some champagne for Gabrielle next to you?" the mother asked, handing the bottle to Lars on her left.  "Gabrielle, please pass the bottle around," she asked and then quickly added, "But no alcohol for my three babies, or anyone under 21 for that matter.  Honey, there's a store downtown that's having a sale on wedding dresses.  Will you have time to go look at some wedding dresses before you leave?"
"Sure Mom," her daughter answered.  "We have a late flight out, so I can do that on the day we leave."
"Michael and I are celebrating New Years Eve at the Sheraton, Waikiki," one of the girls announced.
"What a coincidence," said the boy sitting next to her.  "We're celebrating New Years at the Sheraton, Los Angeles.  It's within walking distance of our apartment so we won't have to worry if we drink too much."
"That sounds like a better plan than we have.  Somehow, just because my car holds a lot of people, I got roped into being the designated driver for the team" Danica said, looking pointedly at her boyfriend, who gestured to the boy from Princeton saying, "he gave me the idea!"
"Girls, your grandmother will be here on Sunday," the father announced.  "She'd really like to see you all."
"Sorry Dad," the business major replied, "we have to leave tomorrow.  There's a huge storm predicted to hit the Eastern United States this weekend and we need to get home before they close the airports.  I noticed that each couple is leaving on a different day for six days after we leave."
"Sir, we're leaving before Sunday also, so we won't be able to make it either.  I'm just glad we don't have to deal with that storm" said the wrestler.
The swimmer and water polo player announced their travel plans.  One of them remarked that even though his girlfriend and he were departing for Oxford University two days earlier, both couples would get home on the same day.
The physics major said "I'll be here to see grandma, but unfortunately we're heading back to California before you go look at the wedding gowns."
"Well I'm glad you'll at least be here to see your grandma, but I wish you could stay longer" the dad said.  "You know you're my favorite since you were my first to major in a physical science like me," he joked.  "I have a tee time at the club on Monday, it's too bad you won't be here," the father remarked to the golfer.  "Kyle's got a game next week but you don't," he said to the history major's boyfriend.  "How about you join me on the links?"
"Sure!" the boyfriend replied enthusiastically.
"Since we're leaving the day after him, if you've got room for two more Dad, we just happened to bring our clubs" the second oldest said, winking at her boyfriend.
"It's a foursome then!" her dad said happily.
Ian grumbled, "Hank you lucky dog, I've wanted to play that course for years!"
The boyfriend of the political science major laughed, "I'd like to play there also, but Ian, at least I won't have to travel as far as you to get another opportunity."
---------
Identify the boyfriend and his sport, the school, and major for each daughter.  Name the order that the daughters were born in and the day of the week that they leave to go home.  What is the seating arrangement at the dinner table?
Bonus question: what year is it?
Hint:
Pay attention to the flow of the conversation, but don't assume more than can be firmly established.
Also, some information relies on the following facts:
Christmas is on December 25th.
New Years Eve is celebrated (usually by drinking too much alcohol) on December 31st.
Swimming, fencing and wrestling are not games.  Football, baseball, water polo and golf are games played with a ball.
Fencing and wrestling are combat competitions.
The game of American football is not a collegiate sport outside the United States; the player that passes the ball is the quarterback; there are more than forty players on a football team.
Water polo is a game played in a pool with 7 players on each team; points are scored by throwing the ball into the opponents net, which is guarded by the goal keeper; the ball is moved across the pool either by swimming with it or passing it to another player.
Ivy League schools are located on the East Coast of the United States.  Harvard, Yale and Princeton are all Ivy League schools.
Oxford University is in Oxford, England.
Tokyo University is in Tokyo, Japan.
Los Angeles and Berkeley are cities in California.
Waikiki is a city in Hawaii.
Hawaii is in the Pacific Ocean.  The following are approximate distances from Hawaii:
Berkeley and Los Angeles ~ 2500 miles
Tokyo ~3900 miles
Yale, Harvard and Princeton ~5000 miles
England ~7000 miles
Biology and physics are physical sciences; none of the other majors is a physical science.
High school in America typically includes the last three or four years of school before college.
A designated driver remains sober in order to drive people who've had too much alcohol home.
A monogram is formed from the first letter of a person's first, last and (sometimes) middle names.
Human Solution:
From oldest to youngest the sisters are:
Who, Boyfriend, Sport, Major, School, Departure day
----------------------------------------------------------
Danica, Hank, Water Polo, History, Yale, Tue
Electra, Edward, Fencing, Philosophy, Princeton, Wed
Angelina, Lars, Golf, Business, Harvard, Fri
Gabrielle, James, Wrestling, Poly Sci., UCLA, Sat
Farrah, Kyle, Football, Physics, Berkeley, Mon.
Brooke, Michael, Baseball, Biology, Tokyo, Thu
Christie, Ian, Swimming, Math, Oxford, Sun
The seating arrangement is:
---------- Dad ----------
Hank.............Danica
Christie..........Ian
Kyle..............Farrah
Electra...........Edward
Michael..........Brooke
Gabrielle........James
Lars..............Angelina
---------- Mom ----------
The year is 2003.  This is the only year from 2000 to 2007 where Christmas is on a Thursday.

Question:
The warden meets with 23 new prisoners when they arrive. He tells them, "You may meet today and plan a strategy. But after today, you will be in isolated cells and will have no communication with one another.
"In the prison there is a switch room which contains two light switches labeled A and B, each of which can be in either the 'on' or the 'off' position. BOTH SWITCHES ARE IN THEIR OFF POSITIONS NOW.*  The switches are not connected to anything.
"After today, from time to time whenever I feel so inclined, I will select one prisoner at random and escort him to the switch room. This prisoner will select one of the two switches and reverse its position. He must move one, but only one of the switches. He can't move both but he can't move none either. Then he'll be led back to his cell."
"No one else will enter the switch room until I lead the next prisoner there, and he'll be instructed to do the same thing. I'm going to choose prisoners at random. I may choose the same guy three times in a row, or I may jump around and come back."
"But, given enough time, everyone will eventually visit the switch room as many times as everyone else. At any time any one of you may declare to me, 'We have all visited the switch room.'
"If it is true, then you will all be set free. If it is false, and somebody has not yet visited the switch room, you will be fed to the alligators."
*note - the only difference from Scenario B, the original position of the 2 switches are known.
Hint:
Assuming that:
A) There is no restriction on the amount of time the prisoners could take before sending the notice to the warden that everyone has been to the switch room at least once.
B) There is no restriction on the number of time each prisoner can visit the switch room
C) The warden will not attempt any foul moves, such as intentionally not bringing a certain prisoner to the switch room forever.
Human Solution:
1.        Appoint a "scorekeeper" and the other 22 prisoners as "transmitters".
2.        When a transmitter enter the switch room for the first time, he will flick switch B ON if he sees it in the OFF position.  Alternatively, he will flick switch A if he sees switch B is in the ON position and waits for his next visit.  The transmitter's mission is to find ONE opportunity to flick switch B to the ON position.  After he completes his mission, he will flick switch A for all subsequent visits.  In short, each transmitter's role is to send a signal to the scorekeeper that he has been to the switch room.
3.        The scorekeeper's role is to flick off switch B whenever he sees it in the ON position.  Each time he flicks off switch B he adds 1 to his score.  When he sees switch B is already OFF, he flicks switch A instead and does not add to the score.  As soon as he accumulates 22, he reports to the Warden.
Response:
The prisoners can agree on the following strategy during their initial meeting.
First, they designate one prisoner as the 'counter'. Let's call this prisoner P1. The other 22 prisoners are P2, P3, ..., P23.
The counter (P1) will be responsible for declaring when everyone has visited. P1 will keep an internal count, starting at zero.
The other 22 prisoners (P2 to P23) will signal that they have visited for the first time, and then signal again on their second visit. On subsequent visits (third and beyond), they will perform a different action.

The strategy for prisoners P2 to P23:
1.  On their first ever visit to the switch room, they must flip switch A. (If A is ON, they turn it OFF. If A is OFF, they turn it ON).
2.  On their second ever visit to the switch room, they must again flip switch A.
3.  On their third and any subsequent visits, they must flip switch B. (If B is ON, they turn it OFF. If B is OFF, they turn it ON).

The strategy for the counter prisoner P1:
1.  P1 keeps an internal count, initialized to 0.
2.  On any visit to the switch room, P1 observes the state of switch A.
3.  If switch A is ON, P1 flips switch A to OFF and increments their internal count by one.
4.  If switch A is OFF, P1 flips switch B. (This action is necessary to fulfill the rule of flipping one switch, and it doesn't interfere with the A-based signaling).
5.  When P1's internal count reaches 44, P1 declares that everyone has visited.

Let's analyze why this strategy works.
There are 22 prisoners (P2 to P23) who are not the counter. Each of these 22 prisoners is required to flip switch A on their first visit and again on their second visit. This means each of these 22 prisoners will contribute exactly two flips to switch A over the course of their first two visits. The total number of times switch A will be flipped by these 22 prisoners on their first or second visits is 22 * 2 = 44.

Switch A starts in the OFF position.
Consider the state of switch A. It can be flipped by prisoners P2-P23 (on their first or second visits) or by P1 (when P1 finds A in the ON position). Switch B is flipped by P2-P23 on their third-or-later visits, and by P1 when P1 finds A in the OFF position. These flips of B do not change the state of A.

P1's counter increments exactly when P1 finds switch A ON and flips it OFF. This means P1 counts the number of times switch A transitions from ON to OFF specifically due to P1's action.

Let's consider the transitions of switch A. A can change from OFF to ON or from ON to OFF.
An OFF to ON transition of switch A can be caused by:
- A prisoner P_i (i != 1) on their first visit, if A is OFF.
- A prisoner P_i (i != 1) on their second visit, if A is OFF.

An ON to OFF transition of switch A can be caused by:
- A prisoner P_i (i != 1) on their first visit, if A is ON.
- A prisoner P_i (i != 1) on their second visit, if A is ON.
- Prisoner P1, if P1 finds A is ON.

P1's count is the number of times P1 performs the A: ON -> OFF transition. For P1 to perform A: ON -> OFF, some prisoner must have performed an A: OFF -> ON transition at some point after the last time A was OFF.

Let's track the cumulative number of times switch A is set to ON.
A prisoner P_i (i != 1) on their first visit: if A is OFF, they set it ON.
A prisoner P_i (i != 1) on their second visit: if A is OFF, they set it ON.
P1 does NOT set A to ON. P1 only sets A to OFF.

The total number of times A is flipped from OFF to ON must equal the total number of times A is flipped from ON to OFF, provided A starts and ends in the OFF state over the period.

Each prisoner P_i (i!=1) makes two flips of A. These flips alternate A's state: OFF->ON->OFF or ON->OFF->ON, relative to its state when P_i visited.
For each prisoner P_i (i!=1), their two flips, occurring at their first and second visits, will have a net effect on the state of A that depends on the state of A when these visits occur.
However, the crucial point is about the *total number of times A is set to ON*.
An A=ON state is set by a prisoner P_i (i!=1) on their first or second visit *only if A was OFF* when they entered.

Let's consider the perspective of P1. P1 counts every time they see A=ON. Each time P1 sees A=ON, they flip it OFF. So A becomes ON, then P1 turns it OFF.
This A=ON state must have been set by one of the P_i (i!=1) on their first or second visit (by flipping A from OFF to ON). A prisoner P_i (i!=1) on their first or second visit who finds A=ON will flip it to OFF, but they would still need another flip to turn it back ON later to be counted this way.

Let's consider the total number of A-flips by P_i (i!=1) on their first two visits (44 total). Each flip reverses the state of A.
Initial A=OFF (0).
After the 1st prisoner (say P2) has their 1st visit, A is flipped.
After P2's 2nd visit, A is flipped again. P2 has caused 2 flips of A.
After all 22 prisoners (P2-P23) have had their first visit, 22 flips of A have occurred (due to their first visits). A is now OFF (since 22 is even, and A started OFF).
After all 22 prisoners (P2-P23) have had their second visit, another 22 flips of A have occurred (due to their second visits). A is now OFF again (since 22 is even, and A was OFF after the first round of visits).

So, by the time every prisoner P_i (i!=1) has visited at least twice, A has been flipped a total of 44 times by these prisoners. A is in the OFF state.
During this time, P1 has also been visiting. When P1 visits and finds A=ON, P1 flips it OFF and increments the count. When P1 visits and finds A=OFF, P1 flips B.

Each time a prisoner P_i (i!=1) flips A from OFF to ON, it contributes to A being ON when P1 might visit.
Each time P1 flips A from ON to OFF, P1 increments the count.

The number of times A changes from OFF to ON must equal the number of times A changes from ON to OFF over any period where A's state is the same at the beginning and end.
P_i (i!=1) on 1st/2nd visit causes A transitions. P1 causes A transitions (only ON->OFF).
The total number of A: OFF->ON transitions caused by P_i (i!=1) (1st/2nd visit) must equal the total number of A: ON->OFF transitions caused by P_i (1st/2nd visit) plus the number of A: ON->OFF transitions caused by P1.

Essentially, P1 is counting the number of times switch A is set to ON by any non-counter prisoner during their first or second visit. Since each of the 22 prisoners sets A to ON exactly once on their first visit (if A is OFF) and once on their second visit (if A is OFF), or ON->OFF and OFF->ON depending on A's state...

The strategy guarantees that P1's count reaches 44 exactly when all 22 non-counter prisoners have completed their second visit. For P1's count to reach 44, switch A must have been found in the ON position by P1 44 times. Each time P1 finds A ON, P1 sets it OFF. A becomes ON only by P_i (i!=1) flipping A on their first or second visit.

Each P_i (i!=1) causes 2 flips of A. These flips contribute to setting A to ON if it was OFF.
The total number of times A is set to ON by P_i (i!=1) over their first two visits is exactly 44. This happens because their action is to always flip A. Regardless of A's state, their flip changes it. If A was OFF, it becomes ON. If A was ON, it becomes OFF (allowing a later prisoner to set it ON).

The total number of times A is set to ON by P_i (i!=1) over their first two visits, summed across all 22 prisoners, is 44. P1's strategy ensures that each time A is set to ON, it is eventually seen by P1 and reset to OFF, incrementing the count.

When P1's count reaches 44, it signifies that 44 events of A being turned ON have been registered by P1. Each of these events must correspond to a flip of A by a prisoner P_i (i!=1) on their first or second visit, that resulted in A being ON when P1 next visited. Given that each P_i (i!=1) flips A twice on their first two visits, and these are the only intended A flips, the count of 44 implies each of the 22 prisoners has completed both their first and second visits.

If every prisoner has visited at least once, P1 has visited at least once, and every P_i (i!=1) has visited at least once. P1 knows they have visited. For P1 to know all others have visited, they need to ensure P2..P23 have visited. P1 counting to 44 based on the prescribed strategy confirms that each of P2..P23 have performed their first and second visit actions (flipping A twice). This implies that each of P2..P23 has visited at least twice, and therefore at least once. Thus, when the count is 44, all 23 prisoners are guaranteed to have visited at least once.

Final check:
- All prisoners can follow the strategy based on their visit number (1st, 2nd, 3rd+) and the switch states they observe.
- P1's action depends only on switch A's state, which is observable. P_i's action depends on visit number and switch state, which is also observable (for state) or trackable internally (for visit number).
- The strategy guarantees that P1 counts a specific event tied to the first two visits of non-counter prisoners.
- The total number of such events (44 A-flips by P2-P23 across their first two visits) provides the target count for P1.

The strategy is:
1.  One prisoner is designated as the counter (P1). P1 starts an internal count at 0.
2.  Other prisoners (P2-P23): On their 1st and 2nd visits, flip switch A. On visits 3+, flip switch B.
3.  P1: If switch A is ON, flip A OFF and increment count. If switch A is OFF, flip switch B.
4.  P1 declares "We have all visited" when their count reaches 44.

Final Answer: The prisoners designate one prisoner as the counter. The counter keeps a tally, starting at zero. The other 22 prisoners agree that on their first visit to the switch room, they will flip switch A. On their second visit, they will again flip switch A. On their third and all subsequent visits, they will flip switch B. The designated counter prisoner agrees that on any visit, if switch A is ON, they will flip switch A OFF and increment their tally by one. If switch A is OFF when they enter, they will flip switch B. When the counter's tally reaches 44, that prisoner declares that all prisoners have visited the switch room.

The final answer is $\boxed{The prisoners can solve this problem.}$.

Question:
There is a ten-digit mystery number (no leading 0), represented by ABCDEFGHIJ, where each numeral, 0 through 9, is used once.  Given the following clues, what is the number?
1) A + B + C + D + E is a multiple of 6.
2) F + G + H + I + J is a multiple of 5.
3) A + C + E + G + I is a multiple of 9.
4) B + D + F + H + J is a multiple of 2.
5) AB is a multiple of 3.
6) CD is a multiple of 4.
7) EF is a multiple of 7.
8) GH is a multiple of 8.
9) IJ is a multiple of 10.
10) FE, HC, and JA are all prime numbers.
Hint: Notice that when combining clues 1 and 2, you have information about the sum of digits. You can do the same for clues 3 and 4.
Human Solution:
5736912480
A = 5, B = 7, C = 3, D = 6, E = 9, F = 1, G = 2, H = 4, I = 8, J = 0
1) 5 + 7 + 3 + 6 + 9 = 30, which is a multiple of 6.
2) 1 + 2 + 4 + 8 + 0 = 15, which is a multiple of 5.
3) 5 + 3 + 9 + 2 + 8 = 27, which is a multiple of 9.
4) 7 + 6 + 1 + 4 + 0 = 18, which is a multiple of 2.
5) 57 is a multiple of 3.
6) 36 is a multiple of 4.
7) 91 is a multiple of 7.
8) 24 is a multiple of 8.
9) 80 is a multiple of 10.
10) 19, 43, and 05 are prime numbers.
A) The sum of digits 0 through 9 is 45.  To satisfy Conditions 1 and 2, a pair of multiples must equal 45.  The only pair that satisfies those conditions are 30 (multiple of 6) and 15 (multiple of 5).  Likewise, to satisfy Conditions 3 and 4, the pair of multiples must be 27 (multiple of 9) and 18 (multiple of 2).
B) Make lists of the multiples of 3, 4, 7, 8, and 10 (for Conditions 5 through 9).  Delete multiples whose digits are the same (33, 44, 66, 77, 88, 99).
C) To satisfy Condition 9, J must be 0.  Delete multiples that require 0 in a different location.  For JA to be prime (Condition 10), A must be: 2, 3, 5, or 7.  Delete multiples of 3 that have another digit for A.
D) For FE and HC to be prime (Condition 10), C and E can not be even or 5.  Delete multiples of 4 and 7 that have another digit for C and E.
E) Per Condition 4, B + D + F + H + J = 18.  D, H, and J must be even (required to form multiples of even numbers).  To attain the sum of 18 (an even number), B and F must either be both odd or both even.  If both are even, then the sum of those five digits would be 20.  B and F must be odd.  Delete multiples of 3 and 7 that have an even digit for B and F.  The only remaining multiple of 7 is 91.  E is 9 and F is 1.  Delete multiples that require 1 or 9 in a different location.
F) The only remaining options for AB contain 7.  Delete multiples that require 7 in a different location.  The only remaining options for CD contain 3.  Delete multiples that require 3 in a different location.
G) To satisfy Condition 1, CD must be 36 and AB must be either 57 or 75.  C is 3 and D is 6.  Delete multiples that require 5, 6, or 7 in a different location.
H) The only remaining options for GH contain 4.  Delete multiples that require 4 in a different location.
I) Per Condition 3, A + C + E + G + I = 27.  Since C =3 and I = 9, the other three must total 15.  There is only one combination of remaining multiples (57, 24, and 80) that can satisfy this condition.  A is 5, G is 2, and I is 8.  B is 7 and H is 4.
